elements.content: This study explores the supramolecular reactivity of the meso-tetra(3-pyridyl)porphyrin (T3PyP) building block in the context of crystal engineering. This ligand has coordination as well as hydrogen bonding tetradentate functionalities and exhibits orientational versatility of the 3-pyridyl substituents. Reactions of the T3PyP with copper and manganese chlorides afforded hybrid coordination polymers with uniquely interesting and novel architectures of three-dimensional connectivity, in which the metal ions have multiple oxidation states. Several different modes of intermolecular association have been observed in crystalline adducts of T3PyP with various aqua nitrate salts of lanthanoid metal ions, which bear multiple molecular recognition sites on their nitrate and water ligands. The porphyrin component in these structures is characterized by differently protonated states. It is either interlinked through the inorganic connectors into self-assembled three-dimensional architectures or exhibits self-complementary hydrogen bonding into homogeneous porphyrin layers which cocrystallized with hydrogen bonded chains of the lanthanoid complex. In addition, the molecular and crystal structures of the freebase ligand, its discrete tin dichloride complex, and polymeric chains of self-coordinated CuT3PyP complex have been characterized as well. These findings demonstrate that the T3PyP scaffold may effectively engage in diverse supramolecular constructs with transition metal ions, either through direct coordination to the metal center or by hydrogen bonding to their coordination sphere ligands, as well as in multiporphyrin self-hydrogen bonded networks.

elements.content: This study demonstrates the versatile supramolecular chemistry of the tetra(3-pyridyl)porphyrin scaffold. New coordination polymers and hydrogen bonded networks were constructed by reacting this ligand with d- and f-transition metal ions, respectively. The framework polymeric assemblies involve Cu and Mn metals in multiple oxidation states. In the hydrogen bonded arrays, the tetradentate porphyrin units are interlinked in three dimensions by pillared lanthanoid nitrate connectors.

In the hydrogen bonded arrays, the tetradentate porphyrin units are interlinked in three dimensions by pillared lanthanoid nitrate connectors.

elements.content: Pyridyl-functionalized porphyrins have been widely utilized in recent years in the construction of multiporphyrin arrays, metal organic frameworks, and supramolecular capsules. The tetra(4-pyridyl)porphyrin derivatives in their freebase (T4PyP) and metalated (MT4PyP) forms deserved particular attention, revealing an extraordinarily rich supramolecular chemistry. In particular, they exhibit a high tendency to readily react through their peripheral N-sites with a variety of transition metal ion connectors and yield hybrid organic−inorganic coordination networks of varying topology and porosity. While ions of the first transition metal row also can be inserted into the tetrapyrrolic core of the porphyrin moiety, those of higher rows (including the lanthanoid ions) can only coordinate either equatorially to the peripheral pyridyl functions, or in a perching fashion to the four pyrrole N-sites from above the macrocyclic core. The metal ions inserted into the porphyrin center may provide additional coordination capacity, allowing self-coordination of the porphyrin entities into framework architectures, without the use of external connectors. Structures of discrete metallosupramolecular boxes, multiporphyrin complexes, and metalloporphyrin complexes with exocyclic pyridyl-coordination of transition metal ions have also been reported. Another aspect of crystal engineering with the T4PyP moiety involves construction of heteromolecular assemblies between the porphyrin moiety and either polycarboxylic acids or aqua nitrate complexes of lanthanoid metal (Ln) ions, which are sustained by hydrogen bonding rather than coordination between the component species. These compounds are characterized by open architectures of two- and three-dimensional (2D and 3D) connectivity, but they represent soft materials which generally collapse upon heating due to the labile nature of the hydrogen bonding interactions. However, several of the coordination driven pyridylporphyrin-based assemblies represent robust materials of potential utility in molecular storage and sorption applications.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Pyridyl-functionalized porphyrins have been widely utilized in recent years in the construction of multiporphyrin arrays, metal organic frameworks, and supramolecular capsules. The tetra(4-pyridyl)porphyrin derivatives in their freebase (T4PyP) and metalated (MT4PyP) forms deserved particular attention, revealing an extraordinarily rich supramolecular chemistry. In particular, they exhibit a high tendency to readily react through their peripheral N-sites with a variety of transition metal ion connectors and yield hybrid organic-inorganic coordination networks of varying topology and porosity. While ions of the first transition metal row also can be inserted into the tetrapyrrolic core of the porphyrin moiety, those of higher rows (including the lanthanoid ions) can only coordinate either equatorially to the peripheral pyridyl functions, or in a perching fashion to the four pyrrole N-sites from above the macrocyclic core. The metal ions inserted into the porphyrin center may provide additional coordination capacity, allowing self-coordination of the porphyrin entities into framework architectures, without the use of external connectors. Structures of discrete metallosupramolecular boxes, multiporphyrin complexes, and metalloporphyrin complexes with exocyclic pyridyl-coordination of transition metal ions have also been reported. Another aspect of crystal engineering with the T4PyP moiety involves construction of heteromolecular assemblies between the porphyrin moiety and either polycarboxylic acids or aqua nitrate complexes of lanthanoid metal (Ln) ions, which are sustained by hydrogen bonding rather than coordination between the component species. These compounds are characterized by open architectures of two- and three-dimensional (2D and 3D) connectivity, but they represent soft materials which generally collapse upon heating due to the labile nature of the hydrogen bonding interactions. However, several of the coordination driven pyridylporphyrin-based assemblies represent robust materials of potential utility in molecular storage and sorption applications.

elements.content: During our continuing crystal engineering investigations of porphyrin-based framework solids, we noticed that the use of the analogous tetra(3-pyridyl)porphyrin building block (T3PyP) to this end was rather rare in earlier studies in spite of the similar tetradentate functionality and molecular recognition potential to that of the widely explored T4PyP. Only a small number of crystalline structures involving complexes and coordination polymers of the T3PyP/MT3PyP entities have been described thus far. They include discrete exocyclic complexes of this ligand with Re and Ru ions, a trimeric supramolecular capsule tessellated by palladium linkers, a 2D coordination network of T3PyP joined by exocyclic coordination to HgI2, and a most recently reported self-coordinated 2D ZnT3PyP assembly where pyridyl functions of one entity link to the zinc centers of adjacent metalloporphyrin species. In order to place these sporadic findings in a wider context, and throw light on the reactivity of T3PyP and its diverse synthons of supramolecular interaction with other components, we report in this study on the preparation and structural characterization of a series of new T3PyP-derived materials. This includes elucidation of the basic forms of the freebase and metalated ligand, its coordination polymers of one- and three-dimensional connectivity with d-transition metals, as well as hybrid assemblies with lanthanoid metal ions sustained by hydrogen bonding.

elements.content: The newly analyzed compounds include the freebase T3PyP (1), the discrete SnIVCl2-T3PyP complex (2), the one-dimensional self-coordinated polymer of CuIIT3PyP (3), 3D polymers of CuIIT3PyP tessellated by tetranuclear (CuICl)4 (4) and (CuII)4 (5) linkers, and a unique 3D polymer of a mixture of MnIIT3PyP and MnIVCl2T3PyP entities, tessellated by MnIICl2 and MnIIICl3 connectors, of complex composition, built around an MnII(DMF)2T3PyP template: [(MnIIT3PyP)2·(MnIVCl2T3PyP)·MnIIICl3·MnIICl2]·MnII(DMF)2T3PyP (6). Another group of compounds was obtained by reactions between T3PyP and nitrates of various lanthanoid metal ions, which reveal hydrogen bonding rather coordination interactions between the organic and inorganic components. These reactions were carried out in an acidic aqueous environment and required a large excess (about 10-fold) of the metal complex. In such conditions, the nitrate ions have a comparable tendency to be present in either a free or a metal-coordinated state, due to competing ion-pairing and coordination interactions, and the pyridyl groups of the porphyrin ligand can be readily protonated to account for charge balance. This is reflected for example in the two different structure types obtained with ytterbium nitrate. One product has a composition of T3PyP·2[YbIII(NO3)3(H2O)2(EtOH)]·o-DCB (7) (o-DCB = o-dichlorobenzene), analogous to that found recently with the T4PyP ligand. The stoichiometric formula of the other compound, (T3PyPH4)4+·2[YbIII(NO3)4(H2O)2 −]·2(NO3 −) (8), indicates protonation of all four pyridyl groups of the porphyrin and incorporation of four additional metal-coordinated as well as noncoordinated nitrate ions in the solid structure. The last compound (T3PyPH2)2+·[Ce(NO3)5·(EtOH)2−·o-DCB (9) is isomorphous with the corresponding La-derivative reported recently. Here, only two of the porphyrin pyridyl groups are protonated, which makes the organic ligand self-complementary for hydrogen bonding with two NH+ proton donor and two N-pyridyl proton acceptor sites. As a result, the cationic and anionic species in 9 form separate hydrogen-bonded arrays in the crystal (via N−H···N and O−H···O interactions, respectively), which interweave into each other. Isomorphous materials were obtained also with Nd, Sm, and Dy in varying experimental conditions, representing a predominant product between T3PyP and aqua nitrates of the earlier lanthanoid ions.

elements.content: There is a considerable similarity between the T4PyP and T3PyP building blocks, in their freebase as well as metalated forms, in the context of crystal engineering. Bearing four diverging pyridyl functions at the meso positions of the porphyrin core, both species are prone to readily coordinate via their pyrrole and pyridyl N-sites to transition metal ions (whether inserted into the porphyrin core or placed in exocyclic positions) and engage in the formation of coordination chains, networks, and complexes. In acidic environments, the neutral pyridyl N-sites reveal a remarkable tendency to attract protons and convert to ionic species, which enhances their capacity to be involved in supramolecular ion-pairing and charge-assisted hydrogen bonding interactions. Numerous examples reported in the literature attest to this versatile supramolecular reactivity of the T4PyP ligand. The main difference between the two ligands is in the substitution pattern of the nitrogen atoms in the peripheral aryl groups. The 4-pyridyl derivative is characterized by one main conformation with the N-sites directed at the four equatorial positions of the porphyrin entity. The disposition of the N-sites in T3PyP is more versatile, as each one of them can point either up or down with respect to the central core, thus potentially enhancing the 3D connectivity features of this unit and the variety of the supramolecular aggregates it may form. On the other hand, the additional flexibility of the T3PyP moiety affects unfavorably the odds of obtaining stable crystalline products of supramolecular ensembles with this scaffold. This is reflected also in a small number of relevant literature reports and emerges from the authors’ experience thus far.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

There is a considerable similarity between the T4PyP and T3PyP building blocks, in their freebase as well as metalated forms, in the context of crystal engineering. Bearing four diverging pyridyl functions at the meso positions of the porphyrin core, both species are prone to readily coordinate via their pyrrole and pyridyl N-sites to transition metal ions (whether inserted into the porphyrin core or placed in exocyclic positions) and engage in the formation of coordination chains, networks, and complexes. In acidic environments, the neutral pyridyl N-sites reveal a remarkable tendency to attract protons and convert to ionic species, which enhances their capacity to be involved in supramolecular ion-pairing and charge-assisted hydrogen bonding interactions. Numerous examples reported in the literature attest to this versatile supramolecular reactivity of the T4PyP ligand. The main difference between the two ligands is in the substitution pattern of the nitrogen atoms in the peripheral aryl groups. The 4-pyridyl derivative is characterized by one main conformation with the N-sites directed at the four equatorial positions of the porphyrin entity. The disposition of the N-sites in T3PyP is more versatile, as each one of them can point either up or down with respect to the central core, thus potentially enhancing the 3D connectivity features of this unit and the variety of the supramolecular aggregates it may form. On the other hand, the additional flexibility of the T3PyP moiety affects unfavorably the odds of obtaining stable crystalline products of supramolecular ensembles with this scaffold. This is reflected also in a small number of relevant literature reports and emerges from the authors' experience thus far.

elements.content: The subject matter of the present report focuses on the supramolecular reactivity of the T3PyP system. For the sake of completeness, we report briefly also on the structures of the nonsolvated freebase T3PyP ligand (1) as well as its metalloporphyrin complex SnCl2T3PyP (2). These were obtained as a byproduct of our supramolecular synthesis effort, but their structures have not been reported before (most commonly tetraaryl porphyrins and porphyrin complexes crystallize as solvates), and crystal structures of their unsolvated forms have rarely been observed. Then, seven new crystalline products of the T3PyP/MT3PyP-based supramolecular assemblies (3−9) were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The crystallographic and experimental data are given in Table . Structures 3−6 involve coordination compounds with d-metal transition metal ions. Compounds 7−9 represent hydrogen-bonded hybrid assemblies of the T3PyP with nitrates of Ln ions.

Figure depicts the molecular structures of 1 and 2. The freebase and the tin-metalated porphyrin cores are essentially planar. In the two structures, the porphyrin framework is characterized by a “chairlike” conformation, where two syn-related pyridyl substituents point upward with respect to the macrocyclic ring, while the other two are oriented in the opposite direction. Similar chair-type conformations have been observed predominantly in the crystal structures of the tetra-(3-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin entity. The crystal packing of the two solvent-free compounds (Figure ) is stabilized by weak C−H···N hydrogen bonding in 1 and C−H···N [C···N = 3.458(5) Å] and C−H···Cl [C···Cl = 3.428(7) Å] interactions in 2, between neighboring porphyrin units, reflecting even in these simple materials the potential role of the pyridyl sites in directing supramolecular organization.

elements.content: Structure of compound 3 (CuIIT3PyP) consists of zigzag-shaped polymeric aggregates which are sustained by coordination between the Cu metal center of one unit and one of the pyridyl groups of a neighboring metalloporphyrin entity (Figure ). The copper ion in 3 is five coordinate with four short Cu−N(pyrrole) bonds within 2.003(2)−2.010(2) Å, and one considerably longer Cu−N(pyridyl) bond of 2.471(2) Å. Although Cu(II) ions with coordination numbers of 5 (or 6) are known in copper complexes with some other ligands, axial coordination to Cu(II) centered within a porphyrin core is rare. This, along with the strong Jahn−Teller effect in this metal ion may explain the long axial coordination distance in 3. The central-Cu ion deviates slightly by 0.120(1) Å from the mean plane of the four surrounding N(pyrrole)-atoms toward the axial ligand. The Cu−N(pyridyl) axial line is perpendicular to the Cu−N4(pyrrole) plane. It deviates, however, by 13.7(1)° from the plane of the axially approaching pyridyl ring. Neighboring polymeric chains are densely packed in the crystalline phase, the zigzag assemblies interdigitating into one another in an efficient manner. The polymeric zigzag chain structure observed in 3 is similar to that observed earlier for the ZnIIT4PyP analogue. Since it involves ligation of only one pyridyl substituent of the T3PyP molecule to the metal center of another metalloporphyrin framework, resemblance to the reported polymeric structure of a monopyridyl-triphenyl-Zn-porphyrin derivative is also evident. Secondary C−H···N interactions (as in 1 and 2) operate between the tightly packed chain-polymeric aggregates.

The polymeric zigzag chain structure observed in 3 is similar to that observed earlier for the ZnIIT4PyP analogue. Secondary C-H⋅⋅⋅N interactions (as in 1 and 2) operate between the tightly packed chain-polymeric aggregates.

elements.content: Crystal structure of 3, showing the one-dimensional polymerization of the CuIIT3PyP units. The Cu ions in the porphyrin core are denoted by small spheres. Note that in 3 the relative orientation of the pyridyl groups is different than in 1 and 2; namely, the trans-related pairs of the pyridyl residues are oriented in opposite directions. Adjacent porphyrin units along the polymeric chains are related to each other by the glide-plane symmetry.

elements.content: In the polymeric chains described above, every porphyrin unit is involved in two coordination bonds to its neighbors. One out of the four peripheral pyridyl residues links to the copper center of an adjacent species, while the five-coordinate metal ion binds to a pyridyl group of a third porphyrin unit. Similar two-point connectivity between the metalloporphyrin units may lead also to the formation of self-coordinated cyclic tetrameric assemblies, which could be considered as supramolecular isomers of the chain-polymeric entities. Such tetrameric isomers are known for the T4PyP ligand, as well as for tetraaryl metalloporphyrins bearing only a single 3-pyridyl function and three other substituents of considerably weaker coordination capacity but are yet to be discovered for the T3PyP scaffold. The MT3PyP and MT4PyP molecules may also behave as tetradentate entities in the self-coordination polymerization process (i.e., without the use of exocyclic metal ions linkers external to the porphyrin macroring). In these compounds, the metal center is six-coordinate, ligating trans-axially to two pyridyl units of two different molecules. In addition, two trans-related pyridyl substituents of a given porphyrin bind to the metal centers of two other adjacent units. Such four-point binding patterns may lead to the formation of either a 2D metalloporphyrin framework as observed for the ZnT4PyP and more recently ZnT3PyP ligands, or to a more robust 3D honeycomb polymeric architecture long known for ZnT4PyP, but still unknown for the MT3PyP entity. Further preparative effort would possibly lead in the future to additional structural forms of the missing self-coordinated polymeric forms of the MT3PyP.

elements.content: Halides of the third row transition metal ions that exhibit multiple oxidation states are known to undergo redox reactions in aqueous systems at elevated temperatures (presence of the DMF weak reductant is particularly helpful to this end). This allows formation of metal−organic frameworks with differently charge ions. Compound 4 (Figure ) is a perfect example of this phenomenon (with CuI ↔ CuII and 2Cl− ↔ Cl2 redox half-reactions), where reaction of the T3PyP with CuIICl2·2H2O yielded a polymeric structure with CuII ions inserted into the porphyrin core and (CuICl)4 tetranuclear clusters (where the halide ions bridge between the copper ions) as the exocyclic interporphyrin linkers. Our studies were stimulated by earlier observations of polymeric copper(I)halide-nitrogen base systems in which the tetrameric copper-halide clusters are bridged in multiple directions by simple nitrogen-base ligands. The use of the tetradentate conformationally flexible T3PyP scaffold provides an excellent opportunity to construct 3D architectures with these building blocks. Realization of this concept in the corresponding reaction products 4 is illustrated in Figure by the polymeric framework of 4. In this framework, the trans-related pairs of 3-pyridyl are oriented either up or down pointing at tetrahedral directions, each linking by N−Cu coordination to the (CuICl)4 cluster at 2.039(5) Å. In the latter, the Cu-ions are placed at the corners of a tetrahedron, and are five-coordinate: to two neighboring coppers, two chloride ions and the pyridyl N-site. Every such tetrameric cluster binds to four different surrounding porphyrin species. This combination of tetrahedrally disposed binding sites on the porphyrin, as well as on the inorganic linkers, yields an open single-framework coordination polymer composed of alternating CuIIT3PyP and (CuICl)4 nodes. Within the tetranuclear cluster, the distance between the proximate Cu ions is 2.766(1) Å, and the Cu−Cl bonds to the bridging Cl-ions are 2.224(2) and 2.235(2) Å. The entire crystal structure of 4 is characterized by tetragonal I41/a space-group symmetry and consists of two interweaving polymeric arrays, where constituents of one array fill efficiently the voids in the other framework. The resulting material represents doubly interpenetrated diamondoid architecture, which is occasionally observed in metal−organic frameworks tessellated by mono/multinuclear inorganic connectors of the preferred tetrahedral coordination environment. An isomorphous polymeric framework 5 was obtained by reacting T3PyP with CuII. Because of the CuI ↔ CuII equilibrium in the given experimental conditions, both ions are present in the product, endocyclic CuII ion and exocyclic (CuIl)4 cluster, as in 4. The corresponding Cu−N, Cu−Cu, and Cu−I bonding distances observed in 5, 2.028(4), 2.736(1), and 2.5376(7), 2.5386(7) Å, respectively, are comparable to those found in 4 considering the larger size of the iodide anion. Because of the interpenetrating architecture of the 3D coordination frameworks, compounds 4 and 5 represent rather robust materials.

elements.content: Triple redox equilibrium MnII ↔ MnIII ↔ MnIV in the reaction mixture between T3PyP and manganese chloride yielded an even more interesting polymeric product 6 of a complex and unexpected composition. The higher 3+ and 4+ oxidation states of this metal could be obtained from the starting MnIICl2 reagent by long exposure of the crystallization mixture to air (O2), and the high propensity of MnIII (once formed) to disproportionate in solution to MnII and MnIV. The asymmetric unit of this material contains two MnIIT3PyP (in different conformations of the pyridyl residues) and one MnIVCl2T3PyP metalloporphyrin species, which interconnect to one another into a framework polymeric array either directly (axial coordination of the 3-pyridyl functions of neighboring porphyrins to the metal center of a given MnIIT3PyP unit), or through exocyclic MnIICl2 and MnIIICl3 connectors. Assembly of the three-dimensional polymeric framework is templated by discrete (i.e., not involved in the coordination polymer) units of the MnII(DMF)2T3PyP complex. Altogether there are four crystallographically unique porphyrin entities and six distinct metal ions in this structure (Figure ). The MnII and MnIV ions are characterized by coordination number of 6 and have an octahedral coordination environment, while the MnIII nodes exhibit coordination number of 5 and coordination sphere of a trigonal bipyramid. As in 4 and 5, all the N-pyridyl sites of porphyrin species involved in the polymeric array are engaged in the coordination to either endocyclic or exocyclic Mn-ions. The MnII(DMF)2T3PyP template fills the voids in the polymeric array and is partly disordered.

elements.content: The supramolecular assembly in this structure can be best described in modular way. It can be considered as composed of layered arrays aligned perpendicular to the c-axis of the unit cell and centered at z = 0 and 1/2, as illustrated in Figure . Within these layers, the MnIVCl2T3PyP unit coordinates via its pyridyl functions to the metal centers of four adjacent MnIIT3PyP entities. Each one of the latter connects axially through the metal center from above and below to two MnIVCl2T3PyPs. Neighboring MnIIT3PyP species further bind to one another through two exocyclic MnCl2 nodes, using two trans-related pyridyl arms. Each of the MnCl2 connectors joins between four adjacent MnIIT3PyP units. The two other pyridyls of the latter are used for interlinking between the 2D layers just described into a 3D framework via the exocyclic MnCl3 pillars (Figure ). Each one of the latter binds trans-axially to two porphyrin scaffolds of consecutive layers. The interlayer open galleries are accommodated by discrete molecules of the MnII(DMF)2T3PyP complex, which are not part of the coordination framework. All coordination distances are within the normal range. The endocyclic Mn−N(pyrrole) bonds in the intercoordinated species are within 2.007(2)−2.028(3) Å. The axial coordinations involving the Mn ions in the porphyrin cores are Mn−N(pyridyl) = 2.352(3)−2.397(3) Å and Mn−Cl = 2.563(1) Å. For the Mn ions of the exocyclic connectors MnIII−Cl = 2.371(1)−2.401(1) Å, MnII−Cl = 2.515(1) Å, and Mn−N(pyridyl) = 2.245(3)−2.350(3) Å. Within the discrete complex Mn−N(pyrrole) = 1.991(4)−1.996(4) Å and Mn−O(DMF) = 2.246(4) Å. All the porphyrin cores are essentially planar. It appears that optimization of the coordination pattern is associated with different conformations of the porphyrin entities, with the subsequent pyridyl rings along the central macrocycle being oriented in an either up−up−down−down (chairlike alignment), or up−down−up−down (“tetrahedral” alignment) fashion.

elements.content: Formulation of analogous coordination polymers of the T3PyP with the lanthanoid f-metal ions is not an easy task, as indicated already in our earlier study with the T4PyP isomer. The coordination affinity of the oxophilic Ln metals for pyridyl sites seems to be rather weak in relation to competing O-ligands (e.g., water, alcohols, carboxylate, and carboxylic acid species). It has been shown, however, that aqua nitrate salts of the lanthanoids (characterized by high coordination numbers) can be used as interporphyrin connectors in hybrid organic−inorganic assemblies, taking advantage of the hydrogen bonding (rather than coordination) features of the porphyrin entity. In the inorganic fragment the nitrate ions and water ligands are tightly coordinated to the metal center and also provide attractive sites for hydrogen bonding with the surrounding moieties. In the supramolecular reaction, multiple hydrogen bonding between the pyridyl groups of T4PyP and the aqua nitrate lanthanoid residue were found to represent a competing interaction to a direct linkage formation between the metal and the pyridyl sites of the porphyrin, yielding hydrogen-bonded (in three dimensions) hybrid polymeric aggregates. It has been anticipated, therefore, that similar supramolecular assemblies could be formulated also with the T3PyP building block.

elements.content: Figure illustrates the hybrid assembly pattern between T3PyP and the nine-coordinate (doubly to three nitrate ions and singly to the two water and one EtOH ligands at Yb−O distances with the range 2.265(3)−2.478(4) Å) lanthanoid-complex connector in 7, Yb(NO3)3(H2O)2(EtOH). The porphyrin entity is planar, resides on inversion centers, and adopts a chairlike conformation regarding the relative orientation of its pyridyl arms. The four diverging pyridyl residues hydrogen bond to four different neighboring lanthanoid complexes via two H2O···N(pyridyl) and two EtOH···N(pyridyl) interactions (characterized by O···N distances of 2.712(5) and 2.670(5) Å, respectively). Every inorganic components hydrogen bonds to the pyridyl groups of two porphyrin units displaced along the ± c direction and further interacts with several neighboring lanthanoid complexes in the ab plane. The latter involve H2O···O(nitrate) hydrogen bonds between the second water ligand and the nitrate proton acceptors (the corresponding O···O hydrogen bonding distances are within 2.739(5)−2.767(5) Å). The lanthanoid and porphyrin species are placed in the crystal in segregated zones parallel to the ab plane of the crystal, being centered at z = 0 and z = 1/2, respectively. In a given inorganic layer, the Yb(NO3)3(H2O)2(EtOH) entities are multiply hydrogen bonded to one another. This, combined with the tetradentate hydrogen bonding pattern exhibited by the porphyrin units, gives rise to a three-dimensionally interconnected assembly. In the lipophilic porphyrin zone, the T3PyP species are arranged in offset-stacked columns, with the disordered molecules of the o-DCB solvent located in the interface between porphyrin species (Figure ).

elements.content: Reactions with the aqua nitrate salts of the lanthanoid metals take place in an aqueous environment. In such acidic conditions, protonation of the peripheral pyridyl groups to a varying degree may readily occur due to Lewis-base nature of the latter. Not surprisingly, therefore, a slight modification of the reaction conditions between the Yb(NO3)3·5(H2O) and T3PyP reagents also may lead to other products, which involve protonation of the pyridyl groups and increased content of the nitrate species in the resulting product. This is demonstrated by structure 8, which is composed of a tetra-protonated porphyrin unit, negatively charged tetra-nitrato complex of the ytterbium(III) ion, and noncoordinated nitrate ions (Figure ). The Yb ion in 8 is also nine-coordinate, linking doubly to three nitrates, singly to another nitrate, as well as to two water ligands (at Yb−O within 2.228(4)−2.479(5) Å). The porphyrin unit resides on centers of crystallographic inversion, being characterized by a chairlike conformation. Given the large number of potential O−H and N−H proton donors and of the nitrate acceptor sites, the supramolecular organization in this structure is netted also by hydrogen bonds avoiding direct porphyrin-metal coordination. The protonated pyridyl sites are involved in charge-assisted hydrogen bonds with four different nitrate ions: two in a free state and two located in the coordination shell of adjacent ytterbium complexes (at corresponding N···O distances of 2.876(7) and 2.933(8) Å). The two anionic inorganic components, [Yb(NO3)4(H2O)2]− and NO3 −, are pillared through hydrogen bonds along the a-axis of the crystal as shown in Figure b. The O−H···O (nitrate) hydrogen bonding interactions (with O···O = 2.675(7), 2.692(6), and 2.902(8) Å) operate between the two anions as well as between units of the Yb-complex displaced along a. The entire structure thus consists of offset-stacked columns of the porphyrin cations, centered at (x, 0, 0), which are interconnected to one another in four different directions via the inorganic pillars centered at (x, 1/2, 1/2) (Figure ). The protonation of the porphyrin in 8, which was not observed in 7, can be attributed to the modification of the crystallization environment, by using the protic 2-propanol solvent in 8 instead of the lipophilic benzene component in 7.

The protonated pyridyl sites are involved in charge-assisted hydrogen bonds with four different nitrate ions: two in a free state and two located in the coordination shell of adjacent ytterbium complexes (at corresponding N⋅⋅⋅O distances of 2.876(7) and 2.933(8) Å). The two anionic inorganic components, [Yb(NO3)4(H2O)2]- and NO3 -, are pillared through hydrogen bonds along the a-axis of the crystal as shown in Figure b. The O-H⋅⋅⋅O (nitrate) hydrogen bonding interactions (with O⋅⋅⋅O = 2.675(7), 2.692(6), and 2.902(8) Å) operate between the two anions as well as between units of the Yb-complex displaced along a. The entire structure thus consists of offset-stacked columns of the porphyrin cations, centered at (x, 0, 0), which are interconnected to one another in four different directions via the inorganic pillars centered at (x, 1/2, 1/2) (Figure ). The protonation of the porphyrin in 8, which was not observed in 7, can be attributed to the modification of the crystallization environment, by using the protic 2-propanol solvent in 8 instead of the lipophilic benzene component in 7.

Note the tetradentate hydrogen bonding functionality (dashed lines) of the T3PyP entities, which link to the Yb-complex and the “free” nitrate ions. (b) Illustration of the hydrogen-bonded pillars of the inorganic components along the a-axis. In the crystal, these pillars connect to four different columns of offset-stacked porphyrin species.

elements.content: Similar reactions of the T3PyP ligand with nitrates of several lighter lanthanoid ions result in a consistent manner in products containing a doubly protonated (T3PyPH2)2+ moiety, as opposed to either the neutral (as in 7) or the quadruply protonated (as in 8) species. The charge balance is achieved in these examples by excessive nitration of the lanthanoid complex: [LnIII(NO3)5(EtOH)]2−. This results in a uniquely interesting situation as the doubly protonated bipyridyl-bipyridinium-porphyrin ions are self-complementary for hydrogen bonding, bearing two proton donors and two proton acceptors. The (T3PyPH2)2+ moieties are then perfectly suited for the self-assembly of hydrogen-bonded networks sustained by N−H···N hydrogen bonds, in clear analogy to the construction of grid assemblies of the tetra(4-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin (via O−H···O bonds) and tetra(4-amidophenyl)porphyrin (via N−H···O bonds) building blocks. First observation of such self-complementary networking with the T3PyP ligand was reported in the preceding paper when T3PyP, was treated with La(NO3)3·6(H2O). In the present work, further and more intensive attempts were made to expose the T3PyP porphyrin to a larger variety of the lanthanoid inorganic reagents, including Ce(NO3)3·6(H2O), Nd(NO3)3·6(H2O), Dy(NO3)3·6(H2O), and Sm(NO3)3·6(H2O) in diverse crystallization conditions. All the resulting products obtained so far appeared, however, to be isomorphous with the lanthanum derivative. Correspondingly, only one additional example was precisely analyzed and will be presented here, namely, (T3PyPH2)2+·[Ce(NO3)5·(EtOH)]2−·o-DCB (9).

elements.content: In 9, the porphyrin units adopt a chairlike conformation, with one pair of cis-related 3-pyridyls being protonated and oriented below the plane of the central core, while the opposite pair of nonprotonated 3-pyridyls pointing above this plane. Correspondingly, the hydrogen bonded networks that form (Figure a) have a wavy/cascaded surface. These networks are aligned parallel to the (1, 0, −1) plane of the crystal, and are sustained by N−H···N hydrogen bonds (N···N = 2.598(9) and 2.638(9) Å). They are characterized by open interporphyrin voids of approximately rectangular shape. The metal complex, in turn, has only one proton donor (the ethanol ligand), which directs the hydrogen-bonding assembly (via OH···O = 2.822(11) Å interactions) of these units into linear chains along the c-axis of the crystal. The Ce-ion in this complex is 11-coordinate (doubly to five nitrate species and singly to the EtOH ligand) with Ce−O distances within 2.501(7)−2.698(9) Å. The inorganic chain arrays, centered at 1/2, 1/2, z, penetrate through the stacked (along the c-axis) hydrogen-bonded nets of the organic assemblies and fill almost completely the interporphyrin voids (Figure ). They are surrounded by columns of the offset-stacked porphyrin scaffolds centered at 1/2, 0, z and 0, 1/2, z. Neither coordination nor hydrogen bonding specific interactions operate between the two domains. Disordered molecules of the o-DCB crystallization solvent accommodate the residual interstitial voids in the crystal lattice.

elements.content: In view of the wide utility of the MT4PyP/T4PyP species in the self-assembly of porphyrin-based networks, this work explores the supramolecular reactivity (in the crystal engineering context) of the closely related 3-pyridyl derivative. The MT3PyP/T3PyP scaffold is characterized by additional degrees of conformational freedom, as the four meso-substituted 3-pyridyl arms can assume alternative orientations with the N-sites positioned either above or below the porphyrin core. This adds versatility to the supramolecular patterns that may form. Two conformers of the T3PyP occur in the above-described examples: (1) the “chair-like” structure with one pair of cis-related pyridyls pointing in one direction and the other pair in the opposite direction, and (b) the “tetrahedral” structure with alternating orientations of adjacent 3-pyridyl substituents along the macrocycle. Preferential occurrence of the chairlike conformation has been observed recently in coordination polymers of the tetra(3-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin scaffold. It imparts a cascaded nature to the layered polymeric aggregate that forms, accompanied by an efficient stacking of such layers along the normal direction. The T3PyP with trans-related 3-pyridyl functions pointing up and the other two down represent a tetrahedral functionality, which may lead to coordination polymers of diamondoid topology when reacted with complementary metal centers of tetrahedral coordination geometry.
elements.clean_text:
Concluding Remarks

In view of the wide utility of the MT4PyP/T4PyP species in the self-assembly of porphyrin-based networks, this work explores the supramolecular reactivity (in the crystal engineering context) of the closely related 3-pyridyl derivative. The MT3PyP/T3PyP scaffold is characterized by additional degrees of conformational freedom, as the four meso-substituted 3-pyridyl arms can assume alternative orientations with the N-sites positioned either above or below the porphyrin core. This adds versatility to the supramolecular patterns that may form. Two conformers of the T3PyP occur in the above-described examples: (1) the "chair-like" structure with one pair of cis-related pyridyls pointing in one direction and the other pair in the opposite direction, and (b) the "tetrahedral" structure with alternating orientations of adjacent 3-pyridyl substituents along the macrocycle. Preferential occurrence of the chairlike conformation has been observed recently in coordination polymers of the tetra(3-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin scaffold. It imparts a cascaded nature to the layered polymeric aggregate that forms, accompanied by an efficient stacking of such layers along the normal direction. The T3PyP with trans-related 3-pyridyl functions pointing up and the other two down represent a tetrahedral functionality, which may lead to coordination polymers of diamondoid topology when reacted with complementary metal centers of tetrahedral coordination geometry.

elements.content: Our study, along with the earlier observation by others, demonstrates the rich supramolecular chemistry that characterizes the T3PyP building block. With transition d-metal ions, in addition to the discrete exocyclic complexes, it can form zero-dimensional oligomeric and 2D polymeric arrays by coordination through exocyclic metal linkers. The MT3PyP derivative has been also engaged successfully in the construction of one-dimensional (compound 3), as well as 2D, polymeric arrays by self-coordination through the metal ion (CuII or ZnII) in the porphyrin core. In view of the remarkable supramolecular isomerism revealed by the MT4PyP analogue, additional MT3PyP-based self-coordinated polymeric aggregates of isomeric connectivity schemes are also envisioned. To our knowledge, the unique polymeric structure types 4−6 have not been observed before with any pyridylporphyrin building blocks. The isomorphous compounds 4 and 5 represent doubly interwoven single-framework coordination polymers composed of the tetrahedral conformer of CuIIT3PyP and a tetranuclear (CuICl)4 or (CuII)4 clusters of complementary tetrahedral topology, as connecting nodes. The conformational and coordination versatility of the T3PyP building block is exhibited to an even wider extent in the formation of the coordination polymeric framework 6. In this structure, both conformers of T3PyP are expressed, and the different and simultaneous coordination modes through metal ions within the porphyrin core as well as external metal ion linkers are manifested. Then, in addition to porphyrin units that are components in the polymeric array, another porphyrin entity is incorporated into the crystal lattice as a template. Multivalent content of MnII, MnIII, and MnIV ions in the same structure represents further uniqueness of compound 6.

elements.content: The final part of this report refers to hybrid assemblies composed of the T3PyP species and nitrate complexes of the lanthanoid f-metal ions, and expands on our recent findings with the T4PyP derivative. The successful construction of these materials is facilitated by the tetradentate functionality and hydrogen bonding capacity of the porphyrin building blocks, as well as the complementary hydrogen bonding features of the inorganic component. The high coordination numbers (between 9 and 11) that usually characterize the lanthanoid metal ions (in their most common 3+ oxidation state) along with versatile hydrogen bonding features of the nitrate, water, or ethanol ligands in their coordination sphere, induce continuous intermolecular interaction schemes between the organic and inorganic species. This is well demonstrated by structures 7 and 8, which are stabilized by extended arrays of supramolecular hydrogen bonding interactions in three dimensions. In 7 the T3PyP units connect to the neighboring inorganic components with the 3-pyridyl sites acting as proton acceptors. In 8 the quadruply protonated T3PyPH4 4+ entity interacts with its neighbors as tetradentate proton donor in four different directions. Compound 9 also represents an interesting hybrid architecture in which the component species form separately hydrogen bonded porphyrin layers and lanthanoid chains that interpenetrate through them. Direct coordination of the T3PyP moieties to the oxophilic lanthanoid ions, scarcely found before for the T4PyP derivative, has not been observed as yet.

The high coordination numbers (between 9 and 11) that usually characterize the lanthanoid metal ions (in their most common 3+ oxidation state) along with versatile hydrogen bonding features of the nitrate, water, or ethanol ligands in their coordination sphere, induce continuous intermolecular interaction schemes between the organic and inorganic species. elements.content: In view of the above findings, there can be little doubt that the rich supramolecular chemistry exhibited by the T3PyP building block will lead in the future to a variety of novel structural variants and attractive multiporphyrin architectures. Programmed design of framework solids based on this ligand may require, however, a considerably more elaborate preparative effort.

elements.content: The porphyrin compound, various lanthanoid salts, and grade solvents were procured commercially and used without further purification. The syntheses were carried out on a mg scale. Compounds 1−9 were obtained by the following procedures:
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Supramolecular Syntheses and Crystallization Procedures

The porphyrin compound, various lanthanoid salts, and grade solvents were procured commercially and used without further purification. The syntheses were carried out on a mg scale. Compounds 1-9 were obtained by the following procedures:

elements.content: LnCl3·7H2O (0.240 mmol) was dissolved in 2 mL of ethanol and mixed with a benzene solution of T3PyP (0.017 mmol, 3 mL). The resulting mixture was refluxed intensively for 2 h. The final cloudy light red solution was filtrated and kept undisturbed for slow evaporation. X-ray quality red crystals of the pure porphyrin freebase component T3PyP were obtained after 40 days. Yield: 92% (based on porphyrin).
elements.clean_text: LnCl3⋅7H2O (0.240 mmol) was dissolved in 2 mL of ethanol and mixed with a benzene solution of T3PyP (0.017 mmol, 3 mL). The resulting mixture was refluxed intensively for 2 h. The final cloudy light red solution was filtrated and kept undisturbed for slow evaporation. X-ray quality red crystals of the pure porphyrin freebase component T3PyP were obtained after 40 days. Yield: 92% (based on porphyrin).

elements.content: T3PyP (0.007 mmol) and SnCl2·2H2O (0.028 mmol) were dissolved in 3 mL of 1:1 methanol/DMF mixture. This solution was placed in a sealed reactor and heated at 120 °C for 3 days in a dry bath. Then, slow cooling of the resulting product for 6 h yielded X-ray quality red rhomb crystals of the SnCl2T3PyP complex. Yield: 44% (based on porphyrin).

This solution was placed in a sealed reactor and heated at 120 °C for 3 days in a dry bath. Then, slow cooling of the resulting product for 6 h yielded X-ray quality red rhomb crystals of the SnCl2T3PyP complex. Yield: 44% (based on porphyrin).

elements.content: T3PyP (0.008 mmol) and Cu(OAc)2·2H2O (0.032 mmol) were dissolved in 3 mL of 1:1 ethanol/DMF mixture and placed in a sealed reactor. Then, one drop of concentrated hydrochloric acid was added to increase the reactants solubility, and the reactor was heated to 100 °C for 3 days in a dry bath. Red crystals were obtained after slow cooling for 6 h. Yield: 56% (based on porphyrin).

The latter was heated to 100 °C for 3 days in a dry bath. Slow cooling for 6 h yielded X-ray quality red crystals of this compound. Yield: 65% (based on porphyrin).

elements.content: T3PyP (0.008 mmol) and CuI (0.047 mmol) were placed in sealed reactor in 2 mL of 1:1 ethanol/DMF solution and heated to 120 °C for 3 days in a dry bath. After slow cooling, X-ray quality very small purple cube crystals were obtained after several hours. Yield: 88% (based on porphyrin).

After slow cooling for 6 h, the resulting solution was filtered and kept undisturbed for slow evaporation. X-ray quality purple crystals were obtained after two months. Yield: 15% (based on porphyrin).

elements.content: Yb(NO3)3·5(H2O) (0.160 mmol) and T3PyP (0.013 mmol) were dissolved in 4 mL of 1:1 ethanol/o-dichlorobenzene mixture. This solution was refluxed overnight, filtered, and carefully covered with a top layer of benzene. Big red crystals in decent yield were obtained after one month.

elements.content: Yb(NO3)3·5(H2O) (0.240 mmol) and T3PyP (0.03 mmol) were completely dissolved in 8 mL of ethanol and 8 mL of o-dichlorobenzene. This solution was refluxed for 3 h and after filtration placed in a small tube, carefully covered with a top layer of isopropanol and left undisturbed for crystallization. After 6 months almost all solvent evaporated, and X-ray quality crystals appeared at the bottom of the tube. The yield could not be determined reliably due to deterioration of the crystals during the drying process.

elements.content: Ce(NO3)3·6(H2O) (0.810 mmol) and T3PyP (0.036 mmol) were dissolved in 18 mL of 1:1 ethanol/o-dichlorobenzene (or m-dichlorobenzene) and refluxed for 5.5 h. The final cloudy solution was filtered and placed in a small tube. It was then carefully covered with a top layer of cyclohexane, to yield red crystals after one month. Isomorphous structures (as indicated by unit-cell measurements) were obtained consistently by similar procedures with Nd(NO3)3·6(H2O) (23% yield), Dy(NO3)3·6(H2O) (35% yield), and Sm(NO3)3·6(H2O), using different “anti-solvent” top layers of cyclohexane, 2-propanol, or benzene. Yield 42% (based on porphyrin).

elements.content: The uniform identity of the formed crystal lattices (1−9) in a given reaction was confirmed in each case by repeated measurements of the unit-cell dimensions from different randomly chosen single crystallites. Because of deterioration of several of the crystalline products (prepared in mg-scale amounts) when taken out from the crystallization solution and/or during the drying process, elemental analysis and powder diffraction experiments could not be carried out reliably in a systematic manner. For their structure determination crystals pulled out from the reaction vials were covered immediately by protective oil and cooled down to 110 K on the diffractometer.

Because of deterioration of several of the crystalline products (prepared in mg-scale amounts) when taken out from the crystallization solution and/or during the drying process, elemental analysis and powder diffraction experiments could not be carried out reliably in a systematic manner. elements.content: The X-ray measurements (Nonius KappaCCD diffractometer, MoKα radiation) were carried out at ca. 110 K on crystals coated with a thin layer of amorphous oil to minimize crystal deterioration, possible structural disorder, and related thermal motion effects, and to optimize the precision of the structural results. These structures were solved by direct methods (SIR-97) and refined by full-matrix least-squares (SHELXL-97). All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were located in idealized/calculated positions and were refined using a riding model; most of those involved in hydrogen bonds were located in difference-Fourier maps but were not refined. In some structures the inner N-pyrrole protons were found disordered between the four possible sites. The crystallographic refinements of structures 1−5, 7, and 8 converged smoothly to relatively low R-values. Compounds 6 and 9 were found to contain disordered crystallization solvent (DMF in 6 and o-DCB in 9). The solvent species could be clearly recognized in difference electron-density maps, but could not be reliably modeled by discrete atoms due to their severe disorder in the interstitial voids. Correspondingly, the contribution of the disordered solvent moieties in 6 and 9 was subtracted from the diffraction pattern by the SQUEEZE procedure and PLATON software. In addition, compound 6 was refined in space group C2/c which imposed location of the porphyrin species on elements of crystallographic symmetry: inversion centers and axes of 2-fold rotation. This structural model required a disordered orientation of two of the pyridyl groups in the isolated porphyrin entity (template) which is not part of the polymeric array. This orientational disordered persisted also in an alternative structural model refined in space group P1̅. It had no effect on the precise description of the polymeric array in this structure. In structure 8, the Yb-ion reveals minor disorder, which represents its possible coordination to two alternative O-sites of the singly ligated nitrate ion.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

The X-ray measurements (Nonius KappaCCD diffractometer, MoKα radiation) were carried out at ca. 110 K on crystals coated with a thin layer of amorphous oil to minimize crystal deterioration, possible structural disorder, and related thermal motion effects, and to optimize the precision of the structural results. These structures were solved by direct methods (SIR-97) and refined by full-matrix least-squares (SHELXL-97). All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were located in idealized/calculated positions and were refined using a riding model; most of those involved in hydrogen bonds were located in difference-Fourier maps but were not refined. In some structures the inner N-pyrrole protons were found disordered between the four possible sites. The crystallographic refinements of structures 1-5, 7, and 8 converged smoothly to relatively low R-values. Compounds 6 and 9 were found to contain disordered crystallization solvent (DMF in 6 and o-DCB in 9). The solvent species could be clearly recognized in difference electron-density maps, but could not be reliably modeled by discrete atoms due to their severe disorder in the interstitial voids. Correspondingly, the contribution of the disordered solvent moieties in 6 and 9 was subtracted from the diffraction pattern by the SQUEEZE procedure and PLATON software. In addition, compound 6 was refined in space group C2/c which imposed location of the porphyrin species on elements of crystallographic symmetry: inversion centers and axes of 2-fold rotation. This structural model required a disordered orientation of two of the pyridyl groups in the isolated porphyrin entity (template) which is not part of the polymeric array. This orientational disordered persisted also in an alternative structural model refined in space group P1̅. It had no effect on the precise description of the polymeric array in this structure. In structure 8, the Yb-ion reveals minor disorder, which represents its possible coordination to two alternative O-sites of the singly ligated nitrate ion.

cln_elements.content:
LnCl3·7H2O (0.240 mmol) was dissolved in 2 mL of ethanol and mixed with a benzene solution of T3PyP (0.017 mmol, 3 mL). The resulting mixture was refluxed intensively for 2 h. The final cloudy light red solution was filtrated and kept undisturbed for slow evaporation. X-ray quality red crystals of the pure porphyrin freebase component T3PyP were obtained after 40 days. Yield: 92% (based on porphyrin).

T3PyP (0.007 mmol) and SnCl2·2H2O (0.028 mmol) were dissolved in 3 mL of 1:1 methanol/DMF mixture. This solution was placed in a sealed reactor and heated at 120 °C for 3 days in a dry bath. Then, slow cooling of the resulting product for 6 h yielded X-ray quality red rhomb crystals of the SnCl2T3PyP complex. Yield: 44% (based on porphyrin).

T3PyP (0.008 mmol) and Cu(OAc)2·2H2O (0.032 mmol) were dissolved in 3 mL of 1:1 ethanol/DMF mixture and placed in a sealed reactor. Then, one drop of concentrated hydrochloric acid was added to increase the reactants solubility, and the reactor was heated to 100 °C for 3 days in a dry bath. Red crystals were obtained after slow cooling for 6 h. Yield: 56% (based on porphyrin).

T3PyP (0.008 mmol) and CuCl2·2H2O (0.042 mmol) were dissolved in 3 mL of 1:1 ethanol/DMF mixture and placed in a sealed reactor. The latter was heated to 100 °C for 3 days in a dry bath. Slow cooling for 6 h yielded X-ray quality red crystals of this compound. Yield: 65% (based on porphyrin).

T3PyP (0.008 mmol) and CuI (0.047 mmol) were placed in sealed reactor in 2 mL of 1:1 ethanol/DMF solution and heated to 120 °C for 3 days in a dry bath. After slow cooling, X-ray quality very small purple cube crystals were obtained after several hours. Yield: 88% (based on porphyrin).

T3PyP (0.008 mmol) and anhydrous MnCl2 (0.038 mmol) were placed in a sealed reactor in 3 mL of 1:1 ethanol/DMF mixture and heated to 120 °C for 3 days in a dry bath. After slow cooling for 6 h, the resulting solution was filtered and kept undisturbed for slow evaporation. X-ray quality purple crystals were obtained after two months. Yield: 15% (based on porphyrin).

Yb(NO3)3·5(H2O) (0.160 mmol) and T3PyP (0.013 mmol) were dissolved in 4 mL of 1:1 ethanol/o-dichlorobenzene mixture. This solution was refluxed overnight, filtered, and carefully covered with a top layer of benzene. Big red crystals in decent yield were obtained after one month.

cln_elements.content: (a) Crystal structure of 1, viewed down the b-axis. (b) Crystal structure of 2 projected down the a-axis. The shortest intermolecular C−H···N (in 1 and 2) and C−H···Cl (in 2) interactions are indicated by dashed lines. They allow tight solvent-free organization of the two compounds.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Crystal structure of 1, viewed down the b-axis. (b) Crystal structure of 2 projected down the a-axis. cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of 3, showing the one-dimensional polymerization of the CuIIT3PyP units. The Cu ions in the porphyrin core are denoted by small spheres. Note that in 3 the relative orientation of the pyridyl groups is different than in 1 and 2; namely, the trans-related pairs of the pyridyl residues are oriented in opposite directions. Adjacent porphyrin units along the polymeric chains are related to each other by the glide-plane symmetry.

Adjacent porphyrin units along the polymeric chains are related to each other by the glide-plane symmetry.

cln_elements.content: (a) The tetrahedral coordination environment around the CuIIT3PyP (top) and (CuICl)4 (bottom) building blocks (ball-and-stick). (b) The three-dimensional coordination framework formed by these components in 4 (wireframe for the porphyrins, and ball-and-stick for the inorganic connectors, representation). The supramolecular organization in 5 is isomorphous. For clarity, only one of the two interweaving frameworks that compose the entire crystal structure is shown in (b).

metadata.title: Versatile Molecular Recognition Features of Tetra(3-pyridyl)porphyrin in Crystal Engineering
